__data__.text: Lateral Movement•Lateral MovementØAttackers will move from a device to a device after the initial hack with the hopes of accessing high-valued data. ØThey will also be looking at ways in which they can gain additional control of the victim's network.ØAt the same time, they will be trying not to trigger alarms or raise any alerts.4Lateral MovementCompromising SystemPrivilege Escalation(External) ReconnaissanceConcluding the mission

__data__.text: Lateral Movement•Lateral MovementØThe attacks are carried out within an organization's network, systems, and premises.ØThis phase of the attack life cycle can take a long time. üIn highly complicated attacks, the phase takes several months in order for the hackers to reach the desired target device.ØThis involves scanning a network for other resources, the collecting and exploiting of credentials, or the collection of more information for exfiltration.5

__data__.text: Network Mapping•Following a successful attack, attackers will try to map out the hosts in a network to discover the ones that contain valuable information.•Many tools can be used to identify the hosts connected in the networksØOne of the most commonly used tools is Nmap.•Nmap can list all hosts that it detects on the network through a host discovery process.ØIt is initialized using commands to scan an entire network.ØWith information gathered, the attacker can go ahead and test the operating system running on computers of interest in a network.7

__data__.text: Network Mapping•Why is network mapping possible?ØBecause of the challenges involved in protecting against it.•Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NDISs) are widely used to prevent the likes of nmap scans. But it has a limited capability when the hackers are scanning individual targets.•When hackers are scanning individual targets, they scan a local segment of a network and thus avoid passing through NDISs.8

__data__.text: Network Mapping•Network intrusion detection systems (NIDSs) shield their systems to prevent internal recon. But, it has a limited capability when the hackers are scanning individual targets.•Host-based intrusion detection systems can prevent the scan from happening. However, most network administrators will not consider Host-based intrusion detection systems in a network, especially if the number of hosts is huge.ØThey lead to more alerts and require more storage capacity and depending on the size of the organization (terabytes of data most of which would be false positives.)ØSecurity teams in organizations have limited resources. Only 4% of all cybersecurity alerts (on average) generated by security systems are investigated.ØThe constant detection of false positives in voluminous quantities also discourages security teams from following up on threats identified in networks.9

__data__.text: Avoiding Alerts•If network administrators detect that there is a threat on the network, they will thoroughly sweep through it and thwart any progress that the attacker will have made.•Security tools can identify many signatures of hacking tools and malware that hackers have been using.•Using legitimate tools for lateral movement ØSecurity systems, therefore, ignore them since they are legitimate.ØIt allows the hackers to move around in highly secured networks.ØFor example, download the file on the web directly using Windows PowerShell.10

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•SysinternalsØA suite of tools that allows administrators to control Windows-based computers from a remote terminal.ØAttackers use Sysinternals to upload, execute, and interact with executables on remote hosts. Those commands can be automated using scripts.ØIt does not give alerts to users on a remote system when it is in operation.ØIt is classified as legitimate system admin tools and therefore are ignored by antivirus programs.ØIt can be used to reveal information about running processes and, if needed, kill them or stop services.ØIt still can be downloaded in (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/sysinternals-suite)11

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•File sharesØPerforming lateral movement in networks that they have already compromised to capture most of the data available in a network.ØUsing legitimate file sharing protocol gives hackers the advantage of low probability of detection since these are legitimate traffic channels that are normally not monitored.ØIt also can be used to plant other bugs in the shared environment to infect the computers that copy files.ØMore effective when the attackers have administrator privileges.12

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•Remote Desktop (Windows)ØAnother legitimate way which is used to access and control computers remotely ØIt can be abused by hackers for the purpose of lateral movement.ØRemote Desktop can be launched when hackers have already compromised a computer inside a network and allows to steal data, disabling security software, or install malware.•ProsØA full interactive graphical user interface (GUI)ØFully encrypted and therefore opaque to any monitoring systems•Cons ØA user working on the remote computer can tell when an external person has logged on to the computer à use Remote Desktop at times when no users are physically on the target.13

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement14•PowerShellØA powerful built-in, object-oriented scripting tool that is available in modern versions of Windows. (legitimate and not detectable)ØSeveral hacking-and security-oriented PowerShell modules such as PowerSploit (https://github.com/PowerShellMafia/PowerSploit) and Nishang (https://github.com/samratashok/nishang) are being used.•How breaches are made by PowerShell: ØThe hackers deployed PowerShell scripts to run as scheduled tasks on Windows machines. ØThe scripts were passed to PowerShell through its command line interface so they did not trigger antivirus programs. ØThe scripts, once executed, downloaded an executable and then were run from a remote access tool.ØNo traces would be left for forensic investigators and they left minimal footprints.

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) ØWMI is Microsoft's inbuilt framework that manages the way in which Windows systems are configured. (legitimate and not detectable)ØThe framework can be used to start processes remotely, to make system information queries, and also store persistent malware if the hacker already has access to the machine.ØWMI was a key tool in a famous hack on Sony Pictures in 2014.ØWMImplant (https://github.com/FortyNorthSecurity/WMImplant) is an example of a hacking tool based on the WMI framework.üWMImplant enables a hacker to give cmd commands, get outputs, modify the registry, run PowerShell scripts, and finally, create and delete services.15

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•Scheduled tasks (In Windows)ØIt needs SYSTEM user privileges to be performed. ØThis removes the hacker from the scene of the crime.ØAttackers can use to steal data over time without raising alarms.•Remote RegistryØRegistry gives control over both the hardware and software of a Windows machine.ØThe Registry can be remotely edited to disable protection mechanisms, disable auto-start programs such as antivirus software, and to install configurations that support the uninterruptible existence of malware.16

ØIt is included in most Windows Server operating systems as a set of processes and services.ØItauthenticatesandauthorizesall users and computers inaWindowsdomain-type network, assigning and enforcing security policies for all computers and installing or updating software.17

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•Active DirectoryØThe richest source of information for the devices connected to a domain network à a key target of an attack.ØThe AD stores the names of users in a network alongside their roles in an organization and allows administrators to change passwords and privileges for users in a network. ØPowerShell commands (from PyroTek3, https://github.com/PyroTek3/PowerShell-AD-Recon) and mimikatz can be used for the reconnaissance on the AD environment and to obtain information about the Kerberos tickets.ØAlso known vulnerabilities such as MS14-068 (https://docs.microsoft.com/en- us/security- updates/securitybulletins/2014/ms14- 068) can be used to get an administrator privilege. 19

__data__.text: Performing Lateral Movement•Breached host analysisØThe attacker will look around on the breached computer for any information that can help him/her move further with the attack such as passwords stored in browsers and text files, logs and screen captures.•Central administrator consolesØless effort to control a device of interest from a console instead of having to break into it every single time. This is the reason why ATM controllers, POS management systems, network administration tools, and active directories are primary targets of hackers.•Email pillaging20

__data__.text: Privilege Escalation•Attackers heighten the privileges of the user accounts that they have compromised to achieve a greater objective:ØMass deletion, corruption, or theft of data, disabling of computers, destroying hardware, and so on.•Many system developers have been employing the least privilege rule, where they assign users the least amount of privileges that are needed to perform their jobs.•Most accounts do not have sufficient rights that can be abused to access or make changes to some files. Hackers will normally compromise these low-privileged accounts and, thus, have to upgrade them to higher privileges in order to access files or make changes to a system.23

__data__.text: Privilege Escalation•Privilege escalation is not a simple phase, as it will at times require the attacker to use a combination of skills and tools in order to heighten the privileges. •There are generally two classifications of privilege escalation: horizontal and vertical privilege escalation.24

__data__.text: Horizontal privilege escalation•In horizontal privilege escalation, the attacker uses a normal account to access the accounts of other users.•Two main waysØThrough software bugs: A normal user is able to view and access files of other users due to an error in the coding of a system.ØThrough an administrator account: attackers can go on with the attack by creating other admin-level users.•Horizontal privilege escalation attacks are normally facilitated by tools and techniques that steal login credentials at the phase where hackers compromise a system.25

__data__.text: Access and Privilege Escalation•In horizontal privilege escalation,ØAn attacker uses the same privileges gained from the initial access.ØA normal user is erroneously able to access the account of another user.ØHorizontal privilege occurs when an attacker is able to access protected resources using a normal user account. ØThis is normally done through session and cookie theft, cross-site scripting, guessing weak passwords, and logging keystrokes.ØAs a result of this escalationüthe attacker normally has well-established remote access entry points into a target system.üThe attacker might also have access to the accounts of several users. üThe attacker knows how to avoid detection from security tools that the target might have. 26

__data__.text: Vertical privilege escalation•More difficult, but more rewarding since the attacker can acquire system rights on a compromised system.•A higher chance of staying and performing actions on a network system whilst remaining undetected. With super user access rights, an attacker can perform actions that the administrator cannot stop or interfere with.•Vertical escalation techniques differ from system to system.ØIn Windows: buffer overflows are commonly used.ØIn Mac: it can be done in a code called jailbreaking.ØAlso, by web-based tools: the exploitation of the code used in the backend.  27

__data__.text: Access and Privilege Escalation•In vertical privilege escalation,ØThe attacker gets access rights and privileges of high level authority such as administrator and a super user. ØThe attacker can run any unauthorized code (e.g., malwares and ransomwares) through the privileges it acquires. ØIt is complex operation. It may need some kernel-level operations to elevate their access rights.ØBuffer overflow is widely used for vertical privilege escalation.ØEternalBlue, which is a vulnerability that is used for WannaCry, is also based on buffer overflow.28

__data__.text: Performing privilege escalation•Privilege escalation technique varies depending onØthe level of skill that the hacker has.Øthe intended outcome of the privilege escalation process.•In Windows, administrator access should be rare and normal users should not have administrative access to systems. Normal employees maintaining admin access open a network to multiple attack vectors.•Remote users have admin accesses to enable them to troubleshoot and solve some issues. When giving remote users admin access, admins should be cautious enough to ensure that this type of access is not used for privilege escalation. 30

__data__.text: Performing privilege escalation•Access token manipulationØWindows normally uses access tokens to determine owners of all running processes. ØThe operating system logs in admin users as normal users, but then executes their processes with admin privileges. Windows uses the run as administrator command to execute processes with the privileges of an administrator.ØAccess token manipulation is highly used in Metasploit. If an attacker can fool the system into believing that processes are being started by an admin, the processes will run without interference with full-level admin privileges.ØAccess token manipulation can also occur when hackers know an admin's credentials. These can be stolen in different types of attacks and then used for access token manipulation.33

__data__.text: Performing privilege escalation•Exploiting accessibility featuresØWindows accessibility features for visual impairments such as the magnifier, screen keyboard, display switch, and narrator can be exploited by the attackers.ØThe attackers can manipulate these features to create a backdoor through which they can log into the system without authentication.ØThis can be done without logging in the Windows.ØBy clicking the manipulated accessibility features, the attacker may get an command prompt with administrator privilege.ØThe attacker can use the command prompt to achieve other tasks. It can open browsers, install programs, create new users with privileges, and even install backdoors.34

__data__.text: Performing privilege escalation•Application shimming (1/2)ØApplication shimming is a Windows Application Compatibility framework.ØMost applications that used to run on Windows XP can today run on Windows 10 due to this framework.ØThe operation of the framework:üIt creates a shim to buffer between a legacy program and the operating system.üDuring execution of programs, the shim cache is referenced to find out whether they will need to use the shim database.üThe shim database will use an API to ensure that the program's codes are redirected effectively. üSince shims are in direct communication with the OS, Windows decides to add a safety feature where they are designed to run in user mode.35

__data__.text: Performing privilege escalation•DLL(Dynamic-link library) is a shared library for the Microsoft-based OS. __data__.text: Performing privilege escalation•DLL search order hijackingØAttackers try to replace legitimate DLLs with malicious ones. ØSince the locations where programs store their DLLs can easily be identified, attackers may place malicious DLLs high up in the path traversed to find the legitimate DLL. à When Windows searches for a certain DLL in its normal location, it will find a DLL file with the same name but it will not be the legitimate DLL (even in the DLLs stored in remote locations)Øthe modification of the ways in which programs load DLLs. Here, attackers modify the manifest or the local direction files to cause a program to load a different DLL than the intended one.•DLL hijacking is complex and it requires lots of caution to prevent abnormal behaviour by the victim program. If the abnormal behaviour is detected, it will be reinstalled by a user.41

__data__.text: Concluding the mission•SustainmentØThe hackers may decide to remain silent even after it exfiltrated all valuable information.ØAttackers install malware, such as rootkit viruses to assure them of access to the victim's computers and systems whenever they want.ØThe victim's security tools are at this point ineffective at either detecting or stopping the attack from proceeding. ØThe attacker normally has multiple access points to the victims, such that even if one access point is closed, their access is not compromised.45

__data__.text: Concluding the mission•ObfuscationØThe attackers cover their tracks.ØThey use various techniques to confuse, deter, or divert the forensic investigation process.•There are a few techniques to obfuscation:ØHackers at times attack outdated servers in small businesses or public schools and then laterally move to attack other servers or targets.ØHackers also can use a free Wi-fi, which is generally not highly protected.ØDynamic code obfuscation: This prevents detection from signature-based antivirus and firewall programs.47

__data__.text: Vulnerability Scanner •Vulnerability scanners automatically inspect the potential exploits on a computer or network to identify security flaws.•A vulnerability scanner has a database of known security holes in services and ports, anomalies in packet construction, and potential paths and to exploitable programs or scripts to the target.•Using a database, it detects and classifies vulnerabilities in hosts, networks and network devices by attempting to exploit each vulnerability that is discovered.•It reports the findings and gives recommended solutions if they are known.4

__data__.text: Authenticated scan vs Unauthenticated scan•In the unauthenticated method, the red team performs the scan as an intruder would, without trusted access to the network. Such a scan reveals vulnerabilities that can be accessed without logging into the network. à similar to external reconnaissance•In an authenticated scan, the red team logs in as a network user, revealing the vulnerabilities that are accessible to a trusted user, or an intruder that has gained access as a trusted user. à similar to internal reconnaissance•Nessus is one of the most popular vulnerability scanners. •OpenVas is well known open source vulnerability scanner.5

__data__.text: Port www (443/tcp)•443/TCP implies HTTPS •Web Server Expect Header XSSØThe remote web server is vulnerable to a cross-site scripting attack.ØThe remote web server fails to sanitize the contents of an 'Expect‘ request header before using it to generate dynamic web content. An unauthenticated remote attacker may be able to leverage this issue to launch cross-site scripting attacks against the affected service, perhaps through specially-crafted ShockWave (SWF) files.ØSolution: Check with the vendor for an update to the web server. For Apache, the issue is reportedly fixed by versions 1.3.35 / 2.0.57 / 2.2.2; for IBM HTTP Server, upgrade to 6.0.2.13 / 6.1.0.1; for IBM WebSphere Application Server, upgrade to 5.1.1.17.11

__data__.text: Port www (443/tcp)•HTTP TRACE / TRACK Methods AllowedØThe remote webserver supports the TRACE and/or TRACK methods. TRACE and TRACK are HTTP methods that are used to debug web server connections.ØSolution: To disable these methods, add the following lines for each virtual host in your configuration file : RewriteEngine on RewriteCond %{REQUEST_METHOD} ^(TRACE|TRACK) RewriteRule .* - [F]   Alternatively, note that Apache versions 1.3.34, 2.0.55, and 2.2 support   disabling the TRACE method natively via the 'TraceEnable‘ directive.12

__data__.text: Nmap Overview•Nmap (https://nmap.org) is a free and open source utility for network discovery and security auditing.•Nmap uses raw IP packets in novel ways to determine Øwhat hosts are available on the network, Øwhat services (application name and version) those hosts are offering, Øwhat operating systems (and OS versions) they are running, Øwhat type of packet filters/firewalls are in use, Øand dozens of other characteristics.•The Nmap suite includes ØZenmap: an advanced GUI and results viewer 17

__data__.text: Nmap Overview•Recap (From Lecture)ØWith Nmap, attackers will try to map out the hosts in a network in order to discover the ones that contain valuable information.ØThe hackers use slower scanning tools that get past all network monitoring systems. The monitoring tools will not detect the scanning activity.ØNmap identifies the unpatched machines.18

__data__.text: Nmap Overview•Basic functions of NmapØBasic command: nmap <option> <target IP Address>•<target IP Address>ØA single host: 192.168.2.4ØGroups of IP addressesüA network using CIDR notation: 192.168.1.0/24üRange of IP addresses: 192.168.3-5,7.1 (This implies 192.168.3.1, 192.168.4.1 , 192.168.5.1 and 192.168.7.1)üList of IP addresses: 10.0.2.4  10.0.2.5 10.0.2.1519

__data__.text: Nmap Overview•<option>ØScanning options:ü-sS : TCP SYN scan. There are more options for TCP scan.ü-sU : UDP scanüScanning outputs will be open, closed, filtered, unfiltered or their combinations.ØTiming options: -T <mode>üParanoid (0), Sneaky (1), Polite (2), Normal (3), Aggressive (4), Insane (5)üThe time interval between two consecutive packets sent to the target are getting shorter as the number increases.üFor example, in Paranoid mode, a packet is sent every 5 minutes and no packets sent in parallel for IDS evasion. In Insane mode, Nmap will not wait for more than 0.3 seconds for a response.20

__data__.text: Nmap OverviewØPort specification üBy default, Nmap will scan the most common 1000 ports in a random orderüOther options are: -p port range: Scan only the defined ports    -F : Scan only 100 most common ports (fast)    -r : Do not randomize port numbers    --top-ports N : Scan the most common N portsØOS Detection (-O): Enable OS detection (This may require a sudo privilege for the user)ØVerbose mode (-v): print out more information on the scanning.ØNo ping (-PN): skip network discovery stageØHost scan: No port scan (-sn), arp scan (-sP)ØVersion detection (-sV)21

__data__.text: Nmap Overview•From version 7, Nmap comes equipped with script function, which makes Nmap more powerful and useful for pentesters.•Commands for script function: nmap --script <script name> <target url or ip>•The scripts cover the following categories:ØAuth:Use to test whether you can bypass authentication mechanismØBroadcast:Use to find other hosts on the network and automatically add them to scanning que.ØBrute:Use for brute password guessing.ØDiscovery:Use to discover more about the network.ØDos:Use to test whether a target is vulnerable to DoS22

__data__.text: Nmap Overview•The scripts cover the following categories:ØExploit:Use to actively exploit a vulnerabilityØFuzzer:Use to test how server responds to unexpected or randomized fields in packets and determine other potential vulnerabilitiesØIntrusive:Use to perform more intense scans that pose a much higher risk of being detected by admins.ØMalware:Use to test target for presence of malwareØSafe:Use to perform general network security scan that's less likely to alarm remote administratorsØVuln:Use to find vulnerabilities on the target23

__data__.text: Nmap Practice•Nmap is portable ØMost operating systems are supported, includingLinux,Microsoft Windows,FreeBSD,OpenBSD,Solaris,IRIX,Mac OS X,HP-UX,NetBSD,Sun OS,Amiga, and more.ØYou can choose Kali, which is a famous offensive operating system and has Namp as a default. ØYou also can install Nmap to the other OS such as Ubuntu, which is one of the most popular Linux distribution.üTo install: sudo apt-get install nmap25

__data__.text: Nmap Practice•One of the simplest ways to get machines with a lot of vulnerabilities is installing metasploitable.ØMetasploitableis an intentionally vulnerable Linux virtualmachinethat can be used to conduct security training, test security tools, and practice common penetration testing techniques.ØYou can download metasploitable 2 in https://sourceforge.net/projects/metasploitable/Ø[Warning] Do not leave metasploitable VM is running, if you are not using it.26
